description: From French ponce, from Latin pūmex. Doublet of pumice.

entries.meaning: (historical) A type of fine powder, as of sandarac, or cuttlefish bone, sprinkled over wet ink to dry the ink after writing or on rough paper to smooth the writing surface.
(historical) Charcoal dust, or some other coloured powder for making patterns through perforated designs, used by embroiderers, lacemakers, etc.

verbs.description: pounce (third-person singular simple present pounces, present participle pouncing, simple past and past participle pounced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sprinkle or rub with pounce powder.
examples: to pounce paper, or a pattern

description: From Middle English pounce, probably akin to punch. Possibly from Old French ponchonner (compare French poinçonner).

entries.meaning: (archaic) The claw or talon of a bird of prey.
examples: You have , indeed , winged ministers of vengeance, who carry your bolts in their pounces to the remotest verge of the sea
a pounce to print money with
one spendeth his patrimony upon pounces and cuts

verbs.description: pounce (third-person singular simple present pounces, present participle pouncing, simple past and past participle pounced)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leap into the air intending to seize someone or something.
examples: The kitten pounced at the ball I threw to it.
She pounced on the young man, because she loved him and wanted him for herself.
I was awakened from a dead sleep by my child pouncing on top of me from out of nowhere.
I pounced on the chance to get promoted.
While he was out of town on vacation, I pounced, leaking the photos.
Why would I talk to the press and give them a chance to pounce on me?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike or seize with the talons; to pierce, as with the talons.
examples: Stooped from his highest pitch to pounce a wren.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stamp holes in; to perforate.
